awd_titl_txt: Dynamics and Control of Hummingbird-Inspired Aerial Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to advance the state of the art in the dynamics and control of flapping-wing flight, enabling creation of a next generation of miniature flying robots, with robustness and agility comparable to natural flyers. Specifically, this project has the goal of creating flying robots with the remarkable flying qualities found in hummingbirds. The insights to enable these advances will be obtained from analytical and computational studies of the role played by wing flexibility in hummingbird flight mechanics, which will be validated experimentally on a hummingbird-like flying robot. Flying robots with these capabilities would play pivotal roles in missions such as search and rescue, environmental monitoring, and emergency response. The project will leverage the inherently intriguing aspect of the robotic hummingbird to cultivate an engaging environment for creative, rigorous application of aerodynamics, dynamics and control theory to motivate a diverse population of students to pursue STEM education and careers. The PI will organize lab visits, summer camps and participate as a guest speaker in K-12 outreach programs for minority and women students and provide research experiences for aerospace graduate and undergraduate students.

This project will improve understanding of the flight dynamics, maneuverability, and disturbance rejection capabilities of realistic hummingbird-like flapping-wing robots through fully nonlinear simulations and flight experiments. Results of the project will include the creation and experimental validation of a fully nonlinear 6-DOF flight dynamics model of a hummingbird-like flapping-wing robot with flexible wings, comprehensive nonlinear simulations and flight tests to identify critical design parameters for stability and controllability of a flapping-wing robot in hover, and control design for maneuverability and disturbance rejection based on identified linear time invariant models. The project will address the role of passive wing-twist in maneuverability, the effect on stability of dynamic coupling between large unsteady wing deflections and the resulting aerodynamic and inertial forces, the role of center of gravity location in stability while hovering, the effect of nonlinearities and modeling uncertainties, and the relation between the flapping wing mechanics and wind gust response. The outcomes will provide increased understanding of the aerodynamic and control mechanisms of natural flight, and show how these mechanisms may be applied to dramatically improve the maneuverability and gust-tolerance capabilities of the next generation of bio-inspired micro air vehicles.

por.por_cntn:
The project has significantly improved our understanding of the dynamics and control of two-winged, hover-capable flapping-wing flight (similar to hummingbirds), which will enable the development of the next generation of miniature flying robots with robustness and agility comparable to natural flyers. Such systems would play pivotal roles in both national defense and domestic safety. An agile, robust, stealthy autonomous flying robot, with the ability to carry miniature sensors could guide soldiers and marines out of harms way. The key research accomplishments include the (1) development of a 60-gram controlled-hover-capable robotic hummingbird, (2) high-fidelity and medium-fidelity aeroelastic and dynamic frameworks, (3) measurements of force, flowfield, elastic-wing-deflection, and vehicle flight dynamics, (4) flight-test-based system identification, (5) control-theoretic analysis to quantify maneuverability and disturbance rejection capability, and (6) comparative studies with a conventional quad-rotor drone. The project trained two PhD students, two female undergraduate students (including an NSF-REU student), and one minority undergraduate student. One of the female undergraduate students is a co-author on a journal paper that was published as part of this study. She was also the recipient of the 2018 NSF Graduate Fellowship and NASA Space Technology Research Fellowship and numerous other university and national level awards. The PI facilitated lab visits, summer camps and participate as a guest speaker in K12 outreach programs with significant number of minority and women students. The project resulted in 3 journal papers published (2 more under preparation), 14 conference papers, 4 best paper awards, and 1 patent.   

 

Major research outcomes are given below.

Development and flight testing of an improved truly biomimetic robotic hummingbird 

The development of a biomimetic robotic hummingbird that utilizes biologically inspired wing kinematic modulation strategies for active stability and control.  By tilting the flapping planes, varying the relative wing flapping amplitude, and shifting the mean position of the flapping stroke, the robotic hummingbird is able to modulate the magnitude, direction, and location of the lift vector of each of the wings in the same way that hummingbirds do to maneuver and stabilize themselves. Flight tests were conducted in which the vehicle was flown in a controlled hover using combinations of control techniques to quantify the effectiveness of each in stabilizing the vehicle. This is the first ever study where the exact kinematic control strategies used by real hummingbirds and two-winged insects are implemented on a robotic flyer and investigated through free-flight testing.

Aeroelastic and Dynamic Frameworks

A computational framework was developed, where a CFD (computational fluid dynamics) solver and a medium-fidelity aerodynamic model are coupled with a nonlinear CSD (computational structural dynamics) solver to simulate dynamics of highly flexible flapping wings with improved fidelity. The aeroelastic analysis was able to predict the variation of lift force and elastic deflections over the course of a flap cycle. The model was able to resolve the forces and salient flow features present on the flapping wing. The deformed wing shapes from the simulation were correlated with the Digital Image Correlation (DIC) measurements. A flight dynamics framework of the robotic hummingbird was developed by coupling the aeroelastic model of the flexible flapping wing with a six degrees of freedom rigid body dynamics model to simulate flexible flapping wing flight. The aeroealstic model quantified the role of wing flexibility on the thrust production, which impacted the control forces and moments generated.

Dynamics of robotic hummingbird vs. quad-rotor drone

In order to compare the maneuverability and gust sensitivity of the robotic hummingbird to a conventional drone, a quad-rotor with the same mass, rotational inertias and CG location as the hummingbird robot was designed and built. The linearized state-space flight dynamic models of both the robots were extracted from targeted flight tests using aircraft system identification techniques. The two aerial robots were systematically compared in terms of gust sensitivity and controllability. The robotic hummingbird is more suceptible to a lateral gust than the quad-rotor. Both the robots had similar sensitivity to longitudinal gust. The hummingbird robot has superior control authority compared to the quad-rotor in both lateral and directional modes. The gust tolerance experiments concurred with the above findings. This the first ever study where the flight dynamics of a hover-capable two-winged flapping wing robot is experimentally compared with a similar multirotor UAV.  This is also the first study to quantify manuverability and gust tolerance of a robotic hummingbird via experiments and a control theoretic method as well as to demonstrate the inherent instability of two-winged flapping flight in hover.
